Award.AwardTitle: Interfacial Wetting and Adhesion Enhancement in Advanced Organic-Fiber/Polymer Composites through a "Nano-nectar" Methodology

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to establish the mechanism that is responsible for wetting and adhesion in organic fiber reinforced polymeric composite materials. Instead of applying fiber surface treatments to the organic fibers that can degrade the organic fiber properties, this methodology involves development of a reactive "nano-nectar" (a "liquid nano-reinforcement") that will lead to reactive nano-matrix materials for improved wettability to the organic fiber surface. Not a simple mixture of nanofiller and polymers, the nano-nectar based reactive nano-epoxy materials are chemically unified and will result in significantly enhanced mechanical properties for their composites. Deliverables include a nanotechnology method for the nano-nectar fabrication, mechanisms of the interfacial wetting/adhesion enhancement, and establishment of the relationships of structure and properties of composites on macro-, micro- and nano-scale levels.

If successful, the results of this research will demonstrate that nanotechnology is an effective tool for improving interfacial wetting/adhesion of fiber composites. It will offer enhanced composite properties without sacrificing the inherent benefits of the organic fibers. Development of such an approach will be a viable alternative for current ineffective surface treatments for organic fibers. Success of this research will initiate new studies on surface and interface science and engineering and will contribute to the development of new lightweight high performance composites for a broad array of industry sectors including aerospace, renewable energy structures, and ground transportation systems. Organic fibers can avoid problems with carbon fibers such as corrosion with metals and importantly, this cost/energy efficient technology may provide a realistic option to the growing demand for carbon fiber composites, which are currently suffering from a global shortage as applications increase. Students with different levels including under-represented groups will benefit from lectures and seminars as well as involvement in the research.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research demonstrates for the first time that nanotechnology becomes a powerful tool for simultaneously improving performance of structural composites and lowering their manufacturing cost/energy via a viable means compatible with conventional facilities in industry. It adds significant knowledge to the science of nanomaterials and nano-manufacturing. The specific project outcomes addressing the intellectual merits and broader impacts, respectively, include:

Intellectual Merits

(1) Initiating new studies of wetting/adhesion: Addition of nanomaterials into polymer systems usually increase viscosity leading to reduced processability for resins. The method created in this project is to convert dry solid nanomaterials, such as carbon nanofibers and nanotubes, into a “solid nano-nectar” , which is so called “liquid nano-reinforcement”. It is for the first time simultaneously improve the performance of polymer resins and decrease their viscosity. The results indicated that introducing polar groups into resins can improve wettability of the resins on solid surface, which has not been paid attention by researchers. This can be explained from that “orange juice has better wettability than water because there are acid groups in orange juice”.

(2) Generating a nano-nectar approach for uniformly dispersing nanomaterials: This project leads to a novel approach to achieving uniform dispersion of nanomaterials and can be realized easily in industry. Due to the excellent compatibility with epoxy resins, the nano-nectar can be uniformly dispersed in epoxy resins via a simple protocol available in current industry, and the resulting nano-epoxy can remain stable through processing of commercial resins and composites. This nano-nectar approach can solve the key issues to all commercial applications of nanofillers: uniform dispersion and good interaction with the matrix. The nano-nectar approach is an innovation with both profound scientific value and tremendous commercial value.

(3) Leading to a novel strategy for simultaneously enhancing properties and lowering manufacturing cost for structural composites: study results indicated that (a) intrinsic values of strength, rigidity, and durability of the nano-epoxy matrix are enhanced. (b) excellent wetting and adhesion of the nano-epoxy with fibers leading to higher interlaminar properties and enhanced durability, and (c) better infusion efficiency is achieved due to the low viscosity and fast wetting capability of the nano-epoxy matrix, which will require lower pressure for resin infusion applications to composite manufacturing. The lower pressure also results in less fiber preform distortion during the flow process, resulting in higher quality part fabrication.  

(4) Proposing a new concept describing wetting behavior of nano-epoxy resin on rough fabric surfaces: A unique wetting behavior of the nano-epoxy on the rough fabric surfaces observed cannot be fully described by existing wetting theories. The conventional contact angle analysis and equipment cannot realize quantitative characterizations of wetting behavior of the nano-modified epoxy resin on rough or fabric surfaces. A more general dry-wet contact concept was developed to characterize the dynamic wetting processes for resins on rough fabric surfaces, which is significant for new interface studies.

Broader Impacts

(1) Broadening application of organic fibers: Organic fibers are light weight and have high mechanical properties, but the poor interfacial adhesion with polymer materials hindered their ap...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This research demonstrates for the first time that nanotechnology becomes a powerful tool for simultaneously improving performance of structural composites and lowering their manufacturing cost/energy via a viable means compatible with conventional facilities in industry. It adds significant knowledge to the science of nanomaterials and nano-manufacturing. The specific project outcomes addressing the intellectual merits and broader impacts, respectively, include: Intellectual Merits (1) Initiating new studies of wetting/adhesion: Addition of nanomaterials into polymer systems usually increase viscosity leading to reduced processability for resins. The method created in this project is to convert dry solid nanomaterials, such as carbon nanofibers and nanotubes, into a "solid nano-nectar" , which is so called "liquid nano-reinforcement". It is for the first time simultaneously improve the performance of polymer resins and decrease their viscosity. The results indicated that introducing polar groups into resins can improve wettability of the resins on solid surface, which has not been paid attention by researchers. This can be explained from that "orange juice has better wettability than water because there are acid groups in orange juice". (2) Generating a nano-nectar approach for uniformly dispersing nanomaterials: This project leads to a novel approach to achieving uniform dispersion of nanomaterials and can be realized easily in industry. Due to the excellent compatibility with epoxy resins, the nano-nectar can be uniformly dispersed in epoxy resins via a simple protocol available in current industry, and the resulting nano-epoxy can remain stable through processing of commercial resins and composites. This nano-nectar approach can solve the key issues to all commercial applications of nanofillers: uniform dispersion and good interaction with the matrix. The nano-nectar approach is an innovation with both profound scientific value and tremendous commercial value. (3) Leading to a novel strategy for simultaneously enhancing properties and lowering manufacturing cost for structural composites: study results indicated that (a) intrinsic values of strength, rigidity, and durability of the nano-epoxy matrix are enhanced. (b) excellent wetting and adhesion of the nano-epoxy with fibers leading to higher interlaminar properties and enhanced durability, and (c) better infusion efficiency is achieved due to the low viscosity and fast wetting capability of the nano-epoxy matrix, which will require lower pressure for resin infusion applications to composite manufacturing. The lower pressure also results in less fiber preform distortion during the flow process, resulting in higher quality part fabrication. (4) Proposing a new concept describing wetting behavior of nano-epoxy resin on rough fabric surfaces: A unique wetting behavior of the nano-epoxy on the rough fabric surfaces observed cannot be fully described by existing wetting theories. The conventional contact angle analysis and equipment cannot realize quantitative characterizations of wetting behavior of the nano-modified epoxy resin on rough or fabric surfaces. A more general dry-wet contact concept was developed to characterize the dynamic wetting processes for resins on rough fabric surfaces, which is significant for new interface studies. Broader Impacts (1) Broadening application of organic fibers: Organic fibers are light weight and have high mechanical properties, but the poor interfacial adhesion with polymer materials hindered their applications. The approach based on fabrication of nano-nectar for reactive nano-matrix that cannot only enhance mechanical properties of resins, but also improve wetting/adhesion of organic fiber/matrix interface without sacrificing the advanced properties of the organic fibers. This creative method can contribute to extending applications of the light organic fibers as composite reinforcements for broader industry sectors, (2) Br...
